nodes.text: Economists' empirical estimates and widely used integrated assessment models (notably DICE) severely underestimate economic damages from climate change and thus are unsuitable for assessing climate risks or guiding policy
Influential economic damage estimates (e.g. Nordhaus/DICE) produce trivially small global GDP damages for large temperature increases (eg 2.1% at 3C, 7.9% at 6C)
Economists' empirical methods contain multiple methodological errors that bias damage estimates downward
The DICE integrated assessment model, given its economic structure and assumptions, is mathematically incapable of producing an economic collapse outcome regardless of damage severity
Climate science indicates tipping points and tipping cascades that are likely within this century at modest warming and would cause large non-linear impacts on habitability and the biosphere
Empirical datasets and IPCC-cited estimates aggregate many studies with point estimates that cluster near small impacts, and Nordhaus calibrated a simple quadratic damage function to such data

Three dominant empirical approaches are flawed: enumeration (omitting large sectors by assuming only weather-exposed sectors are affected), spatial-statistical proxies (using cross-sectional climate-income relations as temporal analogues), and CGE approaches that assume market-driven adaptation and equilibrium

Specific methodological failures include treating indoor/controlled-sector activities as immune to climate change, equating weather exposure with climate vulnerability, and extrapolating regional spatial correlations to global temporal change
DICE embeds the Ramsey growth model with Cobb-Douglas production, full employment, exogenous productivity and population, quadratic damage to output, and convex abatement costs

Sensitivity analysis of DICE to much larger damage coefficients shows the model never yields a systemic economic collapse: it forces corner solutions (full mitigation), extreme parameter responses, temporary deep declines, then recovery as assumed technologies or negative emissions kick in

Peer-reviewed climate literature and expert elicitation identify multiple tipping elements (Arctic sea-ice, Greenland ice sheet, AMOC, etc.), potential tipping cascades, and regional habitability thresholds (e.g., wet-bulb limits) at few-degree warming

Expert elicitation and publication processes produced biased and tightly-connected research communities and sparse refereeing, producing persistent acceptance of the flawed assumptions and small-damage estimates

Alternative empirical and modelling approaches that include tipping probabilities, damages to capital and productivity, and non-equilibrium dynamics produce much larger damage estimates and recommend more stringent mitigation

Given the conceptual, methodological, and modelling failures reviewed, economists' empirical damage estimates and IAMs calibrated to them (e.g. DICE, FUND, PAGE) should not be used to evaluate climate risks or to set policy
